utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Wo de zhing shi Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: No, it’s Wo de ming zi shi Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Wo de ming zi shi Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: What’s this?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: That’s what you did. I assumed as in a number of languages that the gesture was part of the phrase.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Well it’s not.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: How am I supposed to know that? As the teacher it’s your obligation to separate your personal idiosyncrasies from the subject matter.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: You know, I’m really glad you decided to learn Mandarin.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Why?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Once you’re fluent you’ll have a billion more people to annoy instead of me.

utterance.speaker: Leonard (entering)
utterance.content: Hey!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Mai du lui tsa.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: You just called Leonard a syphilitic donkey.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: My apologies Leonard, I’m only as good as my teacher.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Why are you learning Chinese?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I believe the Szechuan Palace has been passing off orange chicken as tangerine chicken and I intend to confront them.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: If I were you, I’d be more concerned by what they’re passing off as chicken.

utterance.speaker: Penny (storming in)
utterance.content: I need to use your window.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, yeah, no, sure, go ahead.

utterance.speaker: Penny (opening window)
utterance.content: Hey Jerkface, you forgot your iPod!

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What’s going on?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, I’ll tell you what’s going on, that stupid self-centred bastard wrote about our sex life in his blog. Drop dead, you stupid self-centred bastard! Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Okay, where were we?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Not now, I have a blog to find.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Penny, are you okay?

utterance.speaker: Penny (voice off)
utterance.content: I’m fine, Leonard, just go away.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Look, I understand that breaking up with someone can be very painful….

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: GO AWAY!

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay, feel better, bye. She doesn’t want to talk.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Not surprising. Penny’s emotional responses originate from the primitive portion of the brain known as the Amygdala, while speech is centred in the much more recently developed Neocortex. The former can easily overpower the latter giving scientific credence to the notion of being rendered speechless. Or maybe she just doesn’t want to talk.

utterance.speaker: Raj (entering)
utterance.content: Hey, look, I found an iPod.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: It’s smashed beyond repair, what are you going to do with it?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: What else? Sell it on ebay as slightly used.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: It was Penny’s boyfriend’s, they broke up.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Apparently he posted intimate details of their physical relationship on his blog, which I cannot find anywhere.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You know what, I’m going to go back and try talking to her again.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Good idea. Sit with her, hold her, comfort her, and if the moment feels right, see if you can cop a feel.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I’m not going to do that, Howard.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m not aware of any social convention that requires you to intervene at all.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What about “damsel in distress?”

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Twelfth century code of chivalry, not exactly current. You’d also have to be knighted for that to apply.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I don’t care. She’s upset, I’m going over there.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Remember to sit on your hands a bit so they’re warm.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I’m her friend, I’m not going to take advantage of her vulnerability.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: What, so you’re saying that if in the depths of despair she throws herself at you and demands you take her, right there, right now, you’ll just walk away?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I said I’m her friend. Not her gay friend.

utterance.speaker: Leonard (knocking and entering)
utterance.content: Hey, listen, I know you said that you didn’t want to talk…

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I don’t.

utterance.speaker: Leonard (leaving)
utterance.content: Sorry.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Wait.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Wait, did you say wait?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Tell me the truth. Am I just an idiot who picks giant losers?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No. No.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, so I pick good guys, but turn them into losers.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Of course not.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well, it’s got to be one or the other, which is it?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I’m sorry, what were the choices again?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I really thought Mike was different, I thought he was sensitive and smart. I mean, not you smart, normal non-freaky smart.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah, no, sure.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: You know, and then he just goes and has to humiliate me by writing about me on his blog so the entire world can read it.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Actually it’s not all that easy to find.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah, really, well my friends at work found it, my sister found it, judging by my email a number of prisoners at the Michigan State Penitentiary found it.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay, well, what exactly did this guy write, not that I need to know the details of your sex life, I just thought…. never mind.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Nope, you know what, you might as well read it, everybody else has, go ahead. Oh God, I just feel so betrayed and embarrassed. I just want to crawl into a hole and die.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay, well, you know, this isn’t that bad. It just paints the picture of a very affectionate woman who’s open to expressing her affection in non traditional locales.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh God!

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Elevators, parks, movie theatres, out of curiosity, is this subway the transportation system or subway the sandwich shop?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Sandwich shop.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Doesn’t that violate the health code?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: No, at the sub shop we were only making out.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Huh. Okay. But my point is that you have absolutely no reason to be embarrassed.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Really, do you think I overreacted?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Maybe a little.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: ‘Cause I do that, I do overreact. Maybe I should call Mike and apologise.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No. No, no, that, that would be underreacting. He did break the implied confidentiality of the bedroom and, in your case, the elevator, parks and fast food franchise.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yes. You’re right. I should just say I’m done with him.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yes, you should, go ahead, say it.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: But I never gave the man a chance to explain.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What is there to explain, it’s all right here, it’s a betrayal.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: No, you were right the first time, this is a man who loves me, but in his own stupid way he was just trying to show people how he feels.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I’m pretty sure I never said that.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: No, you did better than that, you helped me see it on my own.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Aw, good for me. Where are you going?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I’m going over to Mike’s. Leonard, thank you so much.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, sure. Huh, maybe I am her gay friend.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Howard, I’m going to need another Mandarin lesson. I obviously didn’t make my point with those people.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: For God’s sake, Sheldon, if you don’t like the tangerine chicken, don’t order the tangerine chicken.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I like tangerine chicken, I’m not getting tangerine chicken.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Can we please change the subject.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Sure. Tell us again how you screwed up and got Penny back together with her old boyfriend.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Just roll the dice.

utterance.speaker: Raj (rolls and moves)
utterance.content: Enslaved by warlocks, stay here till you roll 2, 4 or 6…7

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: She was mad at him. She was done with him, the relationship was broken beyond repair and I walked over there and I fixed it!

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Boy, that story gets better every time you hear it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Actually, I thought the first two renditions were far more compelling. Previously I felt sympathy for the Leonard character, now I just find him to be whiny and annoying.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Just eat your tangerine chicken.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’d love to, but I don’t have tangerine chicken.

utterance.speaker: Penny (storming in)
utterance.content: Thank you so much for your stupid advice.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Incredible. You managed to screw up the screw-up.

utterance.speaker: Leonard (knocking and entering)
utterance.content: I’m back.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I’m sorry I yelled at you. It’s not your fault.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What happened?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well, I went over to Mike’s to make up with him.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah, I know, I know that part.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: But he had already moved on.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Already, that was quick.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: That’s what I said to the woman who had her legs wrapped around his neck.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, Penny, I am so sorry.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: How could he do that.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, well, you know, you did throw an 8 gig iPod… yeah, no, how could he do that.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I swear to God, I am done with guys like that. You know, macho, with the perfect body and the hair, and the money.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah, that must get old quick.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: You know, just once, I would like to go out with someone who is nice, and honest, and who actually cares about me.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What about me?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: What about you what?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What about if you went out with me?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Are you asking me out?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Um… yes… I am… asking you out.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Wow.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I was just going off your comment about the nice guy…

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: No, I know, I got that. Yeah, totally.

utterance.speaker: Leonard (continuing through Penny)
utterance.content: …thing and honest but, it’s no big deal…

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yes what?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yes, I will go out with you.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Really?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah. Why not, I mean, what do I have to lose?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah. That’s the spirit.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Show me your citrus peels. Gei wo kan, ni jud di zi pei. Show me your citrus peels. Gei wo kan, ni jud di zi pei. Show me your…

utterance.speaker: Penny (tapping him on the shoulder)
utterance.content: Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (jumping in panic)
utterance.content: Aieee ya! Xia si wo le.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I’m sorry. Look, do you have a second.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: A second what? Pair of underwear?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I was just wondering if I could talk to you? It’s about Leonard.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Why me? Why not Koothrappali or Wolowitz?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well, Raj can’t talk to me unless he’s drunk, and Wolowitz is, you know, disgusting.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yes, I suppose he is.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: All I’m saying is, you know Leonard the best.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Not necessarily. I’m often surprised by my lack of familiarity with Leonard. Just the other day I discovered, he not only has a loofah, he hides it. Why do you suppose a man would be ashamed of having a loofah? I myself prefer to have my excess epithelial cells slough off naturally, but I don’t condemn those who seek to accelerate the process. And until recently I had no idea that despite his lactose intolerance, he can tolerate small amounts of non-fat ice cream without producing a noxious gas that I maintain in the right concentration could be weaponised.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Leonard might come home, can we talk in my apartment.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: We’re not done?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Ach, why not? We’re already through the looking glass anyway.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, so, here’s the thing. I guess you’re aware that Leonard asked me out.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, he didn’t actually say anything, but when he came back to the apartment he was doing a dance that brought to mind the happy hippos in Fantasia.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, that’s nice. Anyhow, the thing I wanted to talk to you about is, you know, since Leonard and I have become friends, I was just… want to sit down?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, I wish it were that simple. You see, I don’t spend much time here and so I’ve never really chosen a place to sit.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well, choose.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: There are a number of options and, I’m really not familiar enough with the cushion densities, air flow patterns and dispersion of sunlight to make an informed choice.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Alright, why don’t you just pick one at random, and then if you don’t like it you can sit somewhere else next time.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No, no, that’s crazy. You go ahead and talk while I figure it out.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay. Um, here’s the thing. So, I’ve known for a while now that Leonard has had a little crush on me…

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: A little crush? Well I suppose so, in the same way Menelaus had a little crush on Helen of Troy.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Alright, yeah, I don’t really know who they are…

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well Menelaus was the brother of Agamemnon…

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah, I don’t care, I don’t care. The point is Leonard isn’t the kind of guy I usually go out with.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Leonard isn’t the kind of guy anyone usually goes out with. Would you be open to rotating the couch clockwise thirty degrees?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: No. What I’m saying is, Leonard might be different in a good way. Obviously my usual choices have not worked out so well.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: The last one worked out well for Koothrappali. He got a free iPod. Oh, glare!

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: But on the other hand, if things don’t go well with Leonard, I risk losing a really good friend. I mean, I guess he’s not looking for a fling, he’s the kind of guy that gets into a relationship for, I don’t know, like you would say light years.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I would not say that. No-one would say that, a light year is a unit of distance, not time.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Thank you for the clarification.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Draft. You see people hear the word year and they think duration. Foot pound has the same problem, that’s a unit of work, not of weight.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Right, thanks.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It’s a common mistake.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Not the first one I’ve made today.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Okay. I think this will be my seat.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Sheldon, do you have anything to say that has anything to do with, you know, what I’m talking about.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, let’s see. We might consider Schrodinger’s Cat.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Schrodinger? Is that the woman in 2A?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No. That’s Mrs Grossinger. And she doesn’t have a cat, she has a Mexican hairless, annoying little animal, yip yip yip yip…

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Sheldon!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Sorry, you diverted me. Anyway, in 1935, Erwin Schrodinger, in an attempt to explain the Copenhagen interpretation of quantum physics, he proposed an experiment where a cat is placed in a box with a sealed vial of poison that will break open at a random time. Now, since no-one knows when or if the poison has been released, until the box is opened, the cat can be thought of as both alive and dead.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I’m sorry, I don’t get the point.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well of course you don’t get it, I haven’t made it yet. You’d have to be psychic to get it, and there’s no such thing as psychic.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Sheldon, what’s the point?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Just like Schrodinger’s Cat, your potential relationship with Leonard right now can be thought of as both good and bad. It is only by opening the box that you’ll find out which it is.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, so you’re saying I should go out with Leonard.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No, no, no, no, no, no. Let me start again. In 1935, Erwin Schrodinger…

utterance.speaker: Leonard (pointing)
utterance.content: Two seats right there.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (to two oriental-looking people occupying the other seats)
utterance.content: Chong sho sha pwe. Xie xie.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sheldon, I think I’ve made a mistake.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I can see that. Unless you’re planning on running a marathon, choosing both stuffing and mashed potatoes is a starch filled redundancy.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No, it’s about Penny.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: A mistake involving Penny? Okay, you’ll have to narrow it down.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I don’t think I can go out with her tonight.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Then don’t.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Other people would say “why not?”

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Other people might be interested.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I’m going to talk anyway.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I assumed you would.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Now that I’m actually about to go out with Penny, I’m not excited, I’m nauseous.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Ah, then your meal choice is appropriate. Starch absorbs fluid which reduces the amount of vomit available for violent expulsion.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Right.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You also made a common grammatical mistake, you said nauseous when you meant nauseated. But go on.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sheldon, this date is probably my one chance with Penny, what happens if I blow it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, if we accept your premise, and also accept the highly improbable assumption that Penny is the only woman in the world for you then we can logically conclude that the result of blowing it would be that you end up a lonely, bitter old man with no progeny. The image of any number of evil lighthouse keepers from Scooby Doo cartoons comes to mind.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You’re not helping.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Alright, what response on my part would bring this conversation to a speedy conclusion?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Tell me whether or not to go through with the date.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Schrodinger’s Cat.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Wow, that’s brilliant.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You sound surprised. Mmm, hou zi shui zai li du.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Hi.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hi.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: come on in.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Thank you. You look very nice.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Thank you. So do you.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I made an eight o’clock reservation.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, great, listen, um, maybe we should talk first.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh. Okay. But before you say anything, have you ever heard of Schrodinger’s Cat?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Actually, I’ve heard far too much about Schrodinger’s Cat.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Good.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Alright, the cat’s alive, let’s go to dinner.

utterance.content: Show me your mucus! Your mucus!

utterance.speaker: Owner (in Mandarin)
utterance.content: Blow your own nose and go away.
